@gianm you're right, there's actually two "issues" in #3531: the main problem is that the task doesn't end because a thread doesn't exit which is addressed in #3539, but the OP first posted a stack trace with `java.util.concurrent.RejectedExecutionException: Got Interrupted while adding to the Queue` which turned out to be unrelated to the process being hung. I submitted this PR earlier to make the task exit cleaner on a /stop, and then when OP mentioned the Kafka lookup extension I was able to repro it and submitted the fix to the real issue in #3539.

I think this is a bug and was caused by the #3494 + #3555 chain. Paths should match the relative/absolute nature of druid.storage.storageDirectory, but looks like currently they're always relative.

This may be related to bad HLL columns getting created by realtime indexing. Despite the comment in HLLC:

```
 * This class is *not* multi-threaded.  It can be passed among threads, but it is written with the assumption that
 * only one thread is ever calling methods on it.
 *
 * If you have multiple threads calling methods on this concurrently, I hope you manage to get correct behavior
```

Realtime indexing actually does involve multiple threads calling methods on a HLLC concurrently, if you have hyperUnique metrics. Specifically the indexing thread is calling `add` concurrently with query threads potentially reading stuff out of it when it is passed to `fold`. So the optimization from #3314 to avoid duplication of the BB by saving and restoring the position could cause chaos.

Will do a patch to at least restore "no worse than 0.9.1.1" behavior although not achieve full thread safety.
Patch in #3578.

Apparently it happens because new taskRunner constructed here: https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/d981a2aa02aedfdf18e0bed5848e704bd9597563/indexing-service/src/main/java/io/druid/indexing/overlord/TaskMaster.java#L103 uses the older lifecycle object to start threads and register shutdown hooks, because the new one is instantiated only several lines below in the code. However it's difficult to trace actual execution path because of `@Inject`, `@LazySingleton`, etc. I don't understand from where `Lifecycle` instance is taken here: https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/d981a2aa02aedfdf18e0bed5848e704bd9597563/server/src/main/java/io/druid/guice/ServerModule.java#L55

@cheddar thanks i guess the new UT fix that.

i guess trying to solve the issue that one realtime node is in a non  responsive state, but this suggestion will only work if the handoff did occur, what about other cases ? i don't think it is a valid fix.

It wouldn't benefit the case where the handoff doesn't actually succeed, that's true.  In that case, we would still get non-deterministic results based on which realtime task the broker chooses to send the query to.

In the current world, that status continues through even after handoff has succeeded, this suggested change would make that state end as soon as handoff completes successfully.

Won't this mess up situations where there are multiple partitions? Adding `_handoff` to the version number of the first to handoff will mean it all of a sudden forms a singleton shard set that overshadows the other partitions served from realtime.
Assuming you're using the "expandable" shard sets that are popular with realtime, since they are considered complete no matter what is loaded.
new changes LGTM, :+1:
I think this approach would complicate numeric dimensions, since the key would no longer only contain ints

I haven't double checked the code recently, but I thought hand-off looked for the partition that it handed off or something greater.  Thinking about it, I guess the logic might be that "if it sees a complete partition set with a greater version, then assume handoff succeeded", in which case you are correct, @gianm 

If that's the logic, then I think it should be possible to make the handoff intelligent enough to look for the `_handoff` version instead of the version that it is looking for today.  In that case, it should be exactly equivalent to the handoff logic today, just the broker-published segment will have the non `_handoff` version, no?

Ha, @cheddar, I wasn't even thinking about that problem you're thinking about. I was thinking of a different thing:
1. v=v1;p=0 and v=v1;p=1 exist in rt
2. v=v1_handoff;p=0 shows up on historicals
3. now the broker thinks "oh, wow, version v1_handoff is way better than version v1, I should use that set" – and v=v1;p=1 stops showing up in queries until it's handed off.

Anyway, for the original problem statement, rather than mucking with versions I think it would be way simpler to have the broker prefer non-realtime versions of a segment if they exist. It already knows about realtime vs non-realtime servers for caching reasons, so it has the info it needs to do that.

@drcrallen @b-slim any thoughts on the general idea & API here?

Broadly: looks like the changes are all centered around having more than one lookup map per thing-we-load. So we may load a single json file that has many logical lookups in it. IMO the nice thing about doing it this way is we only have to poll and parse the file one time. It's also easier to configure loading multiple lookups from one file. I'm on board with the general idea and attempting to work out whether the API needs adjustments or not.

LGTM

We are also working at this. We are trying a different approach. In our cases, spark is used for machine learning while druid is to be used as a datasource, so we did't use the historical node because we think it is not designed for high throughout. 
In our approach, a query is split into several steps:
1) query the coordinator for the path of each segments
2) create a SegmentRdd and split need segment queries into different partitions
3) merge the results

I like the idea on minimizing the amount of fetch that a lookup had to make but the current API change make it backward incompatible plus it is unclear what `mapName` really mean. I would highly recommend to work on that by for instance use a name spacing convention like `name.subname` where the name will be used to match on the registered lookup then subname as equivalent to `mapName`.
The second part of review is in progress.
Yes, this is possible with either the [groupBy query](http://druid.io/docs/latest/querying/groupbyquery.html) or [topN query](http://druid.io/docs/latest/querying/topnquery.html).

The problem have been solved. I just use "LZF" instead of "LZ4" to compress dimensions.  But the real reason which causes "LZ4" hanging up peon is still not known yet.

I hope this may help somebody else who have the same problem.

Just wanted to update on this issue :
So the hosted-graphite guys did some more research, and there seems to be a lot of ambiguity around this issue.
Bottom line - they decided to automatically convert forward slashes to periods in metric names (for Pickle protocol only at the moment), since in practice Graphite allows forward slashes.
Colons work fine BTW (as opposed to what we initially thought).

As this is the case and considering @b-slim's comment, I'm closing this issue.

yeah, I remember that one.

There is a race condition between `delete` and the periodic runnable created by `getPostRunnable`

In `getPostRunnable` the syncrhonized lock of the impl datum's AtomicBoolean is acquired, then `swapAndClearCache` may be called. In the off-heap code path this then acquires the `nsLocks` lock for that namespace key.

In `OffHeapNamespaceExtractionCacheManager.delete` the `nsLocks` namespace key lock is acquired, then `super.delete` is called, which calls `removeNamespaceLocalMetadata` which has a sync on the same AtomicBoolean.

So in one case the AtomicBoolean is locked, THEN the overriding class acquires a different lock, and in the other the overriding class acquires a lock, THEN the super class's lock is acquired.

This is really really hard to reproduce in tests, even when I know exactly what race condition I'm trying to evoke.

I'm working on a solution which will probably not be tested in any meaningful way since I can't even get this condition to fire as is.
I just tried upgrading to jetty 9.2.19.v20160908 and the bug still happens when `Expect: 100-continue` is set as a header. It does only affect the router though.
Actually that still happens on 9.3.12.v20160915 too, because the commit that fixes https://github.com/eclipse/jetty.project/issues/277 hasn't hit a release yet.
@hland do you have insight into whether https://github.com/eclipse/jetty.project/issues/277 will be part of the next 9.2.x release? If so I think we should upgrade to that when it's available.
